China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. NOx emissions have raised many environmental problems and posed a serious threat to human health. Development of excellent catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) is desirable. In this study, by ingeniously encapsulating Ce ions into MIL-125 channels, CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts were prepared by annealing the Ce/MIL-125 precursor. Due to the porous framework structure of the MIL-125, a large amount of Ce ions were adsorbed into the pores, thus achieving high dispersion of CeO2 in the composites. All the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts exhibit a NO conversion of nearly 100% at 350 ℃ and a wide temperature range larger than 200 ℃. The CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst shows high specific surface area and porous structure. Meanwhile, a large amount of Ce3+ sites, enriched surface oxygen species, outstanding adsorption of NOx species and high surface acidity for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst account for the excellent NH3-SCR properties with a wide temperature range (200 ℃ ∼ 450 ℃) and excellent H2O and SO2 resistance. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords MIL-125 CeO2 @TiO2 NH3-SCR A wide temperature range Excellent H2O resistance Superior SO2 resistance Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are major air contaminants that seriously endanger the ecology and people's health [1–3]. NOx is generated by the combustion of fossil fuels, including coal and petroleum products. Hence, numerous technologies for eliminating NOx have been utilized [4–7]. Selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR) is seen as an alternative strategy, which has a great possibility of converting NOx into harmless nitrogen and water [8–12]. In the past few years, scientists have conducted a lot of research on SCR denitrification catalysts. Commercial denitrification is generally adopted by V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 catalysts [13]. However, vanadium-based catalysts have toxicity, and narrow operating temperature windows with poor product selectivity [14–16]. The development of excellent SCR catalysts with low operating temperature could be an alternative strategy to avoid SO2 poisoning. Therefore, the reality requires that a superior catalyst must show excellent denitration performance and high environmental tolerance. Many types of metals and their oxides have been applied to NH3-SCR [2,17–21]. Among them, Ce-based catalysts serve as promising materials to remove NOx by SCR due to their excellent oxygen storage and release capacity, as well as redox performance [22]. However, pure CeO2 exhibits poor thermal stability and weak SO2-resistence [23]. Recently, Ce-M (second metal) oxide catalyst strategies, including Ce-Ti [24,25], Ce-Mn [26], Ce-W [27], Ce-P [28], Ce-Mo [29] and ternary catalysts like Ce-Mo/Ti [30], Ce-W/Ti [31], Ce-Cu/Ti [32,33], Ce-Mn/Ti [34], can significantly improve the activity and stability of catalysts. Another effective strategy focuses on adjusting the carrier with sufficient surface area and certain redox/acidic properties to anchor CeO2 components. The synergistic effect between active components promotes the electron transfer and facilitates the adsorption/activation of reactants. TiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, and carbon materials have been studied for loading CeO2 mixed oxides. Luo et al. fabricated four CeO2-TiO2 mixed-oxide catalysts with different exposed facets of TiO2 through a hydrothermal method. The CeO2-TiO2 nanospheres with mainly exposed {111} facet provided abundant Ce-O-Ti short-range structure, which created a series of stronger acidic sites. The abundant stronger acidic sites and Ce3+ species in CeO2-TiO2 nanospheres endowed outstanding NH3-SCR activity [35]. Therefore, designing a carrier that efficiently supports CeO2 catalyst can promote the NH3-SCR activity. TiO2 has been extensively used as the support for SCR catalysts due to its excellent SO2 resistance. Liu et al. prepared CoMn2O4/W-TiO2 composite through a facile method. The high dispersion of W species and greater surface acidity endow the catalyst with superior NH3-SCR performance [36]. MIL-125 composed of basic units of Ti8O8(OH)4-(O2CC6H5-CO2)6 has a porous and crystalline structure with a high thermal stability, large surface area and abundant pores [37,38]. After annealing, MIL-125 precursor can be converted to a robust TiO2 matrix [39]. In this work, CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts were prepared by annealing the Ce loaded MIL-125 precursors. Owing to the porous framework structure of MIL-125, a large amount of Ce ions are adsorbed into the pores, achieving high dispersion of CeO2 in the CeO2 @TiO2 composite after annealing. The obtained CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst possesses good dispersion of active species, favorable specific surface areas, abundant oxygen vacancies and Ce3+ species, and outstanding redox property. Therefore, the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst exhibits superior NH3-SCR activity. 2 Experimental section Preparation of MIL-125(Ti) nanoparticles: The pristine MIL-125(Ti) nanoparticles were synthesized according to the literature [40]. Firstly, 54 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and 6 mL of CH3OH (VDMF / Vmethanol = 9:1) was mixed together. Subsequently, 1.56 mL of tetrabutyl orthotitanate (TBOT) and 3.00 g of 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate (H2BDC) were dispersed in the mixed solvent, then stirred until it became a transparent solution. The mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave and reacted at 150 °C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, the final white powder was collected, washed with methanol and dried in an oven at 80 oC for 12 h. Preparation of CeO2 @TiO2 nanoparticles. The above MIL-125 power (2 g) was dispersed into 120 mL of ethanol (labeled as solution A). Then Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O (x g, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) and hexamethylenetetramine (HMT, HMT: Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O = 1.6:1) were dispersed into 80 mL of deionized water (labeled solution B). Subsequently, the solution B was poured into solution A. The mixed solution was putted into the oil bath for 2 h at 75 °C. The resultant precipitate was collected by centrifugation and dried at 80 °C under vacuum. Finally, the samples were annealed at 400 °C for 5 h (5 °C/min) in air. The samples were named as CeO2 @TiO2 (2/x) catalysts. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Evaluation of catalytic performance A large amount of Ce ions are adsorbed into the pores of porous framework structure of TiO2 precursors, leading to the high dispersion of CeO2 in the composites. The NH3-SCR performance of CeO2 @TiO2 composites are shown in Fig. 1a. All catalysts exhibit good activity with NO conversion of nearly 100% at 350 ℃ and a wide temperature range (∼ 200 ℃). In the high temperature region (> 400 ℃), the NO conversion declines slowly with the increase of CeO2 content. In the low temperature region, the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts with different mass radios (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1) show similar NO conversions. When the mass ratio of CeO2 to TiO2 continues to increase (2/2, 2/3 and 2/4), its conversion rate gradually increases. Furthermore, the temperature window continuously shifts to lower temperature as the radio increases from 2/0.25–2/4. Among them, CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst exhibits superior NH3-SCR performance. Meanwhile, the temperature window of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst is broadened from 200 ℃ to 450 ℃. In addition to excellent activity, N2 selectivity is also a vital index for evaluating NH3-SCR catalysts. Typically, selectivity is generally reflected by assessing the concentration of N2O (the main by-product). The N2O concentrations of all catalysts are ≤ 10 ppm during the whole temperature window (150 ∼ 500 ℃), indicating superior N2 selectivity (Fig. 1b). The above results clearly show that the synergistic effect of CeO2 and TiO2 can significantly improve the activity and selectivity of NH3-SCR performance. 3.2 H2O + SO2 resistance test H2O and SO2 are inevitable in actual industrial and vehicle exhaust gases. However, current metal oxide catalysts are easily deactivated by residual SO2 in the tail gas. Hence, we tested the H2O and SO2 tolerance of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst by introducing them into the reaction process ( Fig. 2). The reaction temperature is fixed at 350 °C during NH3-SCR reaction. In the initially 9 h of the reaction, SO2 and H2O are introduced respectively. The NOx conversions maintain above 98%. Subsequently, it is worth noting that the activity decreases significantly in the presence of H2O and SO2. The NOx conversion of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst decreased significantly and stabilized at around 80%. However, when H2O and SO2 are removed, the NOx conversion recovers rapidly and stabilizes at nearly 93% within an hour. The CeO2 @TiO2 composite can recover most of its activity after cutting off H2O and SO2, but some active sites are still completely deactivated. In short, H2O and SO2 alone do not pose a threat to NH3-SCR performance. Whereas, the H2O and SO2 act together to the deactivation of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) composite. Competitive adsorption on the active sites between H2O and NH3 inhibits the NH3-SCR reaction. Meanwhile, H2O and SO2 promote the deposition of sulfate on the catalyst surface, leading to irreversible deactivation of the active species. 3.3 Characterization of catalyst 3.3.1 Structural and textural analysis The crystal phases of CeO2 @TiO2 samples with different mass ratios (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) are determined by XRD patterns ( Fig. 3a). The diffraction peaks at 25.3°, 37.0°, 37.8°, 38.6°, 48.1°, 54.0°, 55.1°, 62.7°, 68.8°, 70.3°, 75.1° and 82.8° belong to the anatase phase of TiO2 (JCPDS Card No.84–1286). Besides, with the increment of CeO2, the intensity of peaks attributed to the fluorite cubic CeO2 phase (JCPDS Card No.75–0076) at 28.7°, 33.2°, 47.7°, 56.6°, 69.7°, 77.0°, 79.5° and 88.9° increases gradually. In the Raman spectra, the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts gives a characteristic TiO2 Raman band at 142 cm-1 (Fig. 3b)[41]. In addition, the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts exhibit a F2 g vibration mode of fluorite cubic CeO2 at 462 cm-1. The bands at 197, 270, 332, 370, 572, and 640 cm-1 can be summarized as CeTi2O6, indicating the interaction between highly dispersed CeO2 and TiO2 [42,43]. With the increase of CeO2, the characteristic Raman band intensity of CeO2 increased obviously. However, the Raman band intensity of CeO2 shows a weaker intensity for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/4) composite, which can be attributed to the agglomeration of CeO2 particles. To get more details on the morphology and dispersion of active species on CeO2 @TiO2 catalyst, SEM, TEM and EDX mapping are performed. As shown in Fig. 4(a-f), CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts are monodispersed pie structure with the average diameter of 700 nm. During the process of Ce precipitation, a lot of Ce ions enter the MIL-125 skeleton, resulting in a higher dispersion of CeO2 after calcination. As the mass ratio of Ce source increases, more CeO2 nanoparticles were generated, accumulated and diffused over the surface of MIL-125 precursor. The typical TEM images of the as-prepared CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst are presented in Fig. 4g. This image shows that the catalyst has a regular shape and a smooth surface. The corresponding elemental mappings show that Ti, Ce and O elements are dispersed uniformly throughout the catalyst, suggesting the CeO2 active species are uniformly distributed in the composites. In short, NH3-SCR activity may be closely related to the CeO2 active species dispersion on the CeO2 @TiO2 catalyst, and the uniform distribution of active species will endow the catalyst with good SCR performance. Fig. 5a shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore distribution curves of the CeO2 @TiO2 composite catalysts. The curves of all samples demonstrate the existence of slit-like pores and mesoporous structure [43]. The BET surface areas of the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts are 121.56, 119.91, 118.02, 114.07, 111.87, 91.79 m2·g-1, respectively (Fig. 5a and Table 1). The results illustrate that the BET surface area decreases with the increment of mass ratios of CeO2 because more CeO2 are encapsulated into the TiO2 channels. Meanwhile, the introduction of excessive CeO2 particles can cause agglomeration and block the channels. Furthermore, the BJH pore diameters are in the range of 12.3 nm ∼ 7.0 nm (Fig. 5b). The results illustrate that the catalyst maintained a robust structure and CeO2 was homogeneously distributed in the CeO2 @TiO2 composites. 3.3.2 Surface properties The XPS analysis was employed to describe element chemical states and surface defect states. The high-resolution O 1 s spectra could be separated into two peaks ( Fig. 6a): the lattice oxygen species (O2 -, denoted as Oβ) and surface adsorbed oxygen species (O- or O2 2-, denoted as Oα). The peak position at low binding energy is ascribed to Oβ, and another peak at high binding energy around 530.7 eV is assigned to Oα [24,44]. In the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts, the peak area ratio of Oα peak and (Oα +Oβ) total peaks are evaluated by integral calculation of Oα and Oβ peak. The atomic ratio corresponding to the Oα peak over CeO2 @TiO2 composites are over 40%, suggesting the samples have abundant surface adsorbed oxygen species ( Table 2). Especially, the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst demonstrates the highest quantity of surface adsorbed oxygen species with nearly 50% atomic proportion of Oα. The Ce 3d XPS spectra are deconvoluted into eight peaks for all the catalysts (Fig. 6b). According to the literature, the u′ and v′ peaks are attributed to Ce3+, and the other six peaks are assigned to Ce4+ (denoted as u‴, u″, u, v‴, v″ and v) [45–47]. The Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratios are also calculated by integrating the areas of the peaks. The Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+) ratios increase progressively as Ce/(Ce + Ti) increases regularly. For each of the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts, the atomic ratio of Ce3+ is at least 30%, and the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst possesses the highest Ce3+ concentration. Abundant surface oxygen species and Ce3+ sites endow the CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst with superior NH3-SCR activity. 3.3.3 Redox property and surface acidity The reduction properties of CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts are evaluated by H2-TPR technique. As shown in Fig. 7, all catalysts exhibit a major reduction peak and three minor reduction peaks. The H2 consumption has been calculated and collected, listed in Table 3. The main reduction peak (around 480 ℃) is attributed to the reduction of surface Ce sites. The three minor peaks (550–850 ℃) are attributed to Ce4+-O- e4+, Ce3+-O-Ce4+, and bulk CeO2 reduction peaks, respectively [48–50]. Furthermore, H2 consumption corresponding to the reduction peak around 480 ℃ for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) catalysts increases with the increase of CeO2 content. The CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst exhibits the highest total H2 consumption (4.69 μmol·g-1) and the relatively lower reduction temperature, suggesting its better reduction performance. Surface acidity of CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts makes a significant impact on the NH3-SCR activity. NH3-TPD experiments are used to explore the surface acidic properties of all solid catalysts ( Fig. 8). It is obvious that the NH3-TPD results of all the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts exist a broad peak around 100 ℃ and several negligible peaks in the high temperature region (400–800 ℃). It is well known that the desorption temperature of NH3 at weak acid sites is lower than that at strong acid sites. The calculated surface acidity of CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts are listed in Table 4. Among them, CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst possesses the richest weak acid sites and displays abundant medium strength acid sites, which is beneficial to the NH3-SCR performance. NO-TPD test was carried out to acquire information regarding differently adsorbed NO species. The CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst in Fig. 9 shows a strong peak in the low temperature region (LT-peak at 200 °C) and a broad peak at higher temperature region (HT-peak at 400 °C). The LT-peak is attributed to monodentate nitrate, and the HT-peak is assigned to bridged bidentate nitrate decomposition. The results indicate that the total amount of NO desorption increased from 20.77 μmol/g for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/0.25) to 36.66 μmol/g for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3). The nitroso species formed at LT-peak will react with ammonia, while the nitro compounds formed at HT-peak decompose at high temperatures and then react with -NH2. The area ratio between LT-peak and HT-peak can be utilized to evaluate the activity of SCR catalysts. With the increment of Ce, more nitroso species were generated on the surface of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst, leading to an increase in the area ratio between the LT and HT peaks, thus improving SCR activity at low temperatures. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts with different mass ratios (2/x, x = 0.25, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4) were prepared by annealing Ce/MIL-125 precursor. All the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts exhibit a NO conversion of nearly 100% at 350 ℃ and a wide temperature range larger than 200 ℃. The CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst shows the optimal NH3-SCR performance with a wide temperature window from 200 ℃ to 450 ℃ and excellent H2O/SO2 durability at 350 ℃ during the long operation. High Ce3+ concentration (nearly 30%), abundant acid sites and high quantity of surface adsorbed oxygen species improved adsorption capacity of nitrate species for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst. In addition, CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst exhibits the optimal total H2 consumption and the lower reduction temperature, suggesting the stronger reduction performance. Furthermore, the outstanding adsorption of NO species facilitate the NH3-SCR activity of CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst at low temperatures. coredata.dc:description: NOx emissions have raised many environmental problems and posed a serious threat to human health. Development of excellent catalysts for selective catalytic reduction of NOx by NH3 (NH3-SCR) is desirable. In this study, by ingeniously encapsulating Ce ions into MIL-125 channels, CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts were prepared by annealing the Ce/MIL-125 precursor. Due to the porous framework structure of the MIL-125, a large amount of Ce ions were adsorbed into the pores, thus achieving high dispersion of CeO2 in the composites. All the CeO2 @TiO2 catalysts exhibit a NO conversion of nearly 100% at 350 ℃ and a wide temperature range larger than 200 ℃. The CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst shows high specific surface area and porous structure. Meanwhile, a large amount of Ce3+ sites, enriched surface oxygen species, outstanding adsorption of NOx species and high surface acidity for CeO2 @TiO2 (2/3) catalyst account for the excellent NH3-SCR properties with a wide temperature range (200 ℃ ∼ 450 ℃) and excellent H2O and SO2 resistance.
coredata.dc:title: A superior CeO2 @TiO2 catalyst with high dispersion of CeO2 for selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3
